If you keep incrementing `index` by `1`, it will eventually point *beyond* the last item in the `animals` array. If this happens you can set `index` back to `0`. It’s then ready to loop through the array again.
After incrementing `index`, check if it’s equal to `animals.count`. If it is, set `index` equal to `0`, so that it points back to the first item in the array.

### Well done!
Remember that the index to an array starts at 0—the first item—and goes up to the array’s count minus 1—the last item. So if the index *equals* the count, the index has gone past the end of the array, and it’s time to set the index back to 0.
